title: Saturated set
summary: In mathematics, particularly in the subfields of set theory and topology, a set C {\displaystyle C} is said to be saturated with respect to a function f : X → Y {\displaystyle f:X\to Y} if C {\displaystyle C} is a subset of f {\displaystyle f} 's domain X {\displaystyle X} and if whenever f {\displaystyle f} sends two points c ∈ C {\displaystyle c\in C} and x ∈ X {\displaystyle x\in X} to the same value then x {\displaystyle x} belongs to C {\displaystyle C} (that is, if f ( x ) = f ( c ) {\displaystyle f(x)=f(c)} then x ∈ C {\displaystyle x\in C} ). Said more succinctly, the set C {\displaystyle C} is called saturated if C = f − 1 ( f ( C ) ) . {\displaystyle C=f^{-1}(f(C)).}
